{{Use British English|date=October 2016}} '''High-altitude adaptation in humans''' is an instance of [[evolutionary adaptation|evolutionary modification]] in certain human populations, including those of [[Tibetan people|Tibet]] in Asia, the [[Andes]] of the Americas, and [[People of Ethiopia|Ethiopia]] in Africa, who have acquired the ability to survive at extremely high [[altitudes]]. This adaptation means irreversible, [[adaptive evolution|long-term physiological responses]] to high-altitude environments, associated with heritable [[ethology|behavioural]] and [[mutation|genetic changes]].
While the rest of the human population would suffer serious health consequences, the indigenous inhabitants of these regions thrive well in the highest parts of the world. These people have undergone extensive physiological and genetic changes, particularly in the regulatory systems of oxygen [[respiratory system|respiration]] and blood [[circulatory system|circulation]], when compared to the general lowland population.<ref name=fris>{{cite book|author=Frisancho AR|title=Human Adaptation and Accommodation|year=1993|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-K_SYHBo42MC&pg|pages=175–301 |isbn =0472095110|publisher=University of Michigan Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author=Hillary Mayell |title=Three High-Altitude Peoples, Three Adaptations to Thin Air|date=24 February 2004 | url=http://news.nationalgeographic.co.in/news/2004/02/0224_040225_evolution.html |work=National Geographic News |publisher=National Geographic Society |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
This special [[adaptation]] is now recognised as an example of [[natural selection]] in action.<ref name=bigh>{{cite journal|author=Bigham A, Bauchet M, Pinto D, Mao X, Akey JM, Mei R, Scherer SW, Julian CG, Wilson MJ, López Herráez D, Brutsaert T, Parra EJ, Moore LG, Shriver MD |year=2010 |title=Identifying signatures of natural selection in Tibetan and Andean populations using dense genome scan data | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1001116 |journal=PLOS Genetics |volume=6 |issue=9|pages=e1001116|pmid=20838600 |pmc=2936536 |doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1001116|last2=Bauchet |last3=Pinto |last4=Mao |last5=Akey |last6=Mei |last7=Scherer |last8=Julian |last9=Wilson |last10=López Herráez |last11=Brutsaert |last12=Parra |last13=Moore |last14=Shriver }}</ref> The adaptation account of the Tibetans has become the fastest case of [[human evolution]] in the scientific record, as it is estimated to have occurred in less than 3,000 years.<ref>{{cite web|author =Sanders R |title=Tibetans adapted to high altitude in less than 3,000 years|url=http://newscenter.berkeley.edu/2010/07/01/tibetan_genome/ | date=1 July 2010 |work=News Centre, UC Berkeley |publisher=UC Regents|accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author =Hsu J |title=Tibetans Underwent Fastest Evolution Seen in Humans |url=http://www.livescience.com/6663-tibetans-underwent-fastest-evolution-humans.html | date=1 July 2010| work=Live Science | publisher=TechMediaNetwork.com| accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref><ref name=yi>{{cite journal |last1=Yi |first1=X. |last2=Liang|first2=Y. |last3=Huerta-Sanchez |first3=E. |last4=Jin |first4=X. |last5=Cuo |first5=Z. X. P. |last6=Pool |first6=J. E. |last7=Xu |first7=X. |last8=Jiang |first8=H. |last9=Vinckenbosch |first9=N. |last10=Korneliussen |first10=T. S. |last11=Zheng |first11=H. |last12=Liu |first12=T. |last13=He |first13=W. |last14=Li |first14=K. |last15=Luo |first15=R. |last16=Nie |first16=X. |last17=Wu |first17=H. |last18=Zhao |first18=M. |last19=Cao |first19=H. |last20=Zou |first20=J. |last21=Shan |first21=Y. |last22=Li |first22=S. |last23=Yang |first23=Q. |last24=Asan |last25=Ni |first25=P. |last26=Tian |first26=G. |last27=Xu |first27=J. |last28=Liu |first28=X. |last29=Jiang |first29=T. |last30=Wu |first30=R. |last31=Zhou |first31=G. |last32=Tang |first32=M. |last33=Qin |first33=J. |last34=Wang |first34=T. |last35=Feng |first35=S. |last36=Li |first36=G. |last37=Huasang |last38=Luosang |first38=J. |last39=Wang |first39=W. |last40=Chen |first40=F. |last41=Wang |first41=Y. |last42=Zheng |first42=X. |last43=Li |first43=Z. |last44=Bianba |first44=Z. |last45=Yang|first45=G. |last46=Wang |first46=X. |last47=Tang|first47=S. |last48=Gao |first48=G. |last49=Chen|first49=Y. |last50=Luo |first50=Z. |last51=Gusang |first51=L. |last52=Cao |first52=Z. |last53=Zhang|first53=Q. |last54=Ouyang |first54=W. |last55=Ren |first55=X. |last56=Liang |first56=H. |last57=Zheng|first57=H. |last58=Huang|first58=Y. |last59=Li |first59=J. |last60=Bolund |first60=L. |last61=Kristiansen |first61=K. |last62=Li |first62=Y. |last63=Zhang |first63=Y. |last64=Zhang |first64=X. |last65=Li |first65=R. |last66=Li |first66=S. |last67=Yang |first67=H. |last68=Nielsen |first68=R. |last69=Wang |first69=J. |last70=Wang|first70=J. |title=Sequencing of 50 human exomes reveals adaptation to high altitude |journal=Science |year=2010 |volume=329 |issue=5987 |pages=75–78 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/329/5987/75 |pmid=20595611 |pmc=3711608 |doi=10.1126/science.1190371 |displayauthors=8 |bibcode=2010Sci...329...75Y}}</ref>
Modern humans [[Recent African origin of modern humans|dispersed from Africa less than 100,000 years ago]], and eventually colonized the rest of the world,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Templeton, A. R. |year=2002|url=http://www.bioguider.com/ebook/biology/pdf/Templeton_n2002.pdf |title=Out of Africa again and again |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=416 |pages=45–51 |doi=10.1038/416045a |issue=6876}}</ref> including the harshest environments of extreme [[polar climate|cold]] and [[alpine climate|high mountains]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jeong|first1=Choongwon |last2=Di Rienzo |first2=Anna|title=Adaptations to local environments in modern human populations |journal=Current Opinion in Genetics & Development |year=2014 |volume=29 |pages=1–8 |doi=10.1016/j.gde.2014.06.011 |pmid=25129844 |pmc=4258478}}</ref> The abundance of [[oxygen]] in the [[atmosphere]] is inversely related to [[altitude]] from the [[sea level]]; hence, the highest mountain ranges of the world are considered unsuitable for human habitation.
Nevertheless, around 140 million people, just under 2% of the world's human population, live permanently at high [[altitude]]s, that is, at heights above {{convert|2,500|m|ft}} in [[South America]], [[East Africa]], and [[South Asia]]. These populations have done so for [[millennium|millennia]] without apparent complications.<ref name=moor>{{cite journal|author=Moore LG |year=1983 |title=Human genetic adaptation to high altitude| url=http://anthro.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.an.12.100183.001441?requestedContent=related& |journal=High Altitude Medical Biology |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=257–279 |pmid=11443005 |doi=10.1089/152702901750265341}}</ref> The overwhelming majority, over 98% of humans from other parts of the world, normally suffer symptoms of [[altitude sickness]] in these regions, often resulting in life-threatening [[Major trauma|trauma]] and even death.
Studies on the detail biological mechanism have revealed that adaptation of the Tibetans, Andeans and Ethiopians is indeed an observable instance of the process of natural selection in acting on [[fitness (biology)|favourable characters]] such as enhanced [[respiratory system|respiratory mechanisms]] in humans.<ref name=mue>{{cite book|author =Muehlenbein, MP |year=2010 |title=Human Evolutionary Biology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1VXX1jkhPH8C&pg|publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK |pages=170–191 |isbn=0521879485}}</ref><ref name=bea07>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM |year=2007|title=Detecting natural selection in high-altitude human populations | journal=Respir Physiol Neurobiol |volume=158|issue=2–3|pages=161–171 |pmid=17644049 |doi=10.1016/j.resp.2007.05.013 }}</ref>
==Origin and basis== [[File:Himalayas-Lhasa15.JPG|thumb|upright|Himalayas, on the southern rim of the Tibetan Plateau]]
[[Homo sapiens|Humans]] are naturally adapted to [[lowland]] environment where oxygen is abundant.<ref name=moo>{{cite journal|author=Moore LG, Regensteine JG|year=1983 |pmid=|title=Adaptation to High Altitude| url=http://anthro.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.an.12.100183.001441?requestedContent=related& |journal=Annual Review of Anthropology |volume=12 |pages=285–304 |doi=10.1146/annurev.an.12.100183.001441 |last2=Regensteiner }}</ref> When people from the general lowlands go to altitudes above {{convert|2,500|m|ft}}, with atmospheric pressure 74% of normal<ref>[https://www.mide.com/pages/air-pressure-at-altitude-calculator Air pressure at altitude calculator]</ref>{{cn|date=May 2018}} they experience [[altitude sickness|mountain sickness]], which is a type of [[hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]], a clinical syndrome of severe lack of oxygen. Complications include [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], [[dizziness]], [[breathlessness]], [[headaches]], [[insomnia]], [[malaise]], [[nausea]], [[vomiting]], [[cramp|body pain]], [[Anorexia (symptom)|loss of appetite]], [[Tinnitus|ear-ringing]], [[frost bite|blistering]] and [[cyanosis|purpling of the hands and feet]], and [[vasodilation|dilated veins]].<ref name=pen>{{cite journal |author=Penaloza D, Arias-Stella J| title=The heart and pulmonary circulation at high altitudes: healthy highlanders and chronic mountain sickness |journal=Circulation |volume=115 |issue=9 |pages=1132–1146|year=2007 |url=http://circ.ahajournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17339571 |pmid=17339571 |doi=10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.106.624544| last2=Arias-Stella }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=León-Velarde F, Villafuerte FC, Richalet JP | title=Chronic mountain sickness and the heart |journal=Prog Cardiovasc Dis |volume=52 | issue=6 |pages=540–549 |year=2010 |doi=10.1016/j.pcad.2010.02.012 |pmid=20417348| last2=Villafuerte | last3=Richalet }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Wheatley K, Creed M, Mellor A | title=Haematological changes at altitude |journal=J R Army Med Corps|volume=157 | issue=1 |pages=38–42 |year=2011 |doi=10.1136/jramc-157-01-07|pmid=21465909| last2=Creed | last3=Mellor }}</ref>
The sickness is compounded by related symptoms such as [[high altitude cerebral edema|cerebral oedema (swelling of brain)]] and [[high altitude pulmonary edema|pulmonary oedema (fluid accumulation in lungs)]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Paralikar SJ| title=High altitude pulmonary edema-clinical features, pathophysiology, prevention and treatment |journal=Indian J Occup Environ Med |volume=16| issue=2|pages=59–62 |year=2012|doi=10.4103/0019-5278.107066 |pmid=23580834| pmc=3617508 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Eide RP 3rd, Asplund CA | title=Altitude illness: update on prevention and treatment |journal=Curr Sports Med Rep |volume=11| issue=3|pages=124–30 |year=2012 |doi=10.1249/JSR.0b013e3182563e7a |pmid=22580489 | last2=Asplund }}</ref> For several days, they [[hyperventilation|breathe excessively]] and [[hypermetabolism|burn extra energy]] even when the body is [[basal metabolic rate|relaxed]]. The [[heart rate]] then gradually decreases. Hypoxia, in fact, is one of the principal causes of death among mountaineers.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Huey RB, Eguskitza X, Dillon M| title=Mountaineering in thin air. Patterns of death and of weather at high altitude |journal=Adv Exp Med Biol |volume=502 |issue=|pages=225–336|year=2001 |pmid=11950141 |doi=| last2=Eguskitza | last3=Dillon }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Firth PG, Zheng H, Windsor JS, Sutherland AI, Imray CH, Moore GW, Semple JL, Roach RC, Salisbury RA| title=Mortality on Mount Everest, 1921-2006: descriptive study |journal=British Medical Journal |volume=337|issue=|pages=a2654|year=2008 |pmid=19074222 |pmc=2602730 |doi=10.1136/bmj.a2654| last2=Zheng | last3=Windsor | last4=Sutherland | last5=Imray | last6=Moore | last7=Semple | last8=Roach | last9=Salisbury }}</ref> In women, pregnancy can be severely affected, such as development of [[hypertension|high blood pressure]], called [[preeclampsia]], which causes [[preterm birth|premature labour]], [[low birth weight]] of babies, and often [[complications of pregnancy|complicated]] with [[haemorrhage|profuse bleeding]], [[seizures]], and [[maternal death|death of the mother]].<ref name=fris /><ref>{{cite journal |author=Moore LG, Shriver M, Bemis L, Hickler B, Wilson M, Brutsaert T, Parra E, Vargas E| title=Maternal adaptation to high altitude pregnancy An experiment of nature A review |journal=Placenta |volume=25 |issue=suppl | pages=S60–S71 |year=2004 |doi=10.1016/j.placenta.2004.01.008| last2=Shriver | last3=Bemis | last4=Hickler | last5=Wilson | last6=Brutsaert | last7=Parra | last8=Vargas | pmid=15033310}}</ref>
More than 140 million people worldwide are estimated to live at an elevation higher than {{convert|2500|m|ft}} above sea level, of which 13 million are in Ethiopia, 1.7 million in Tibet (total of 78 million in [[Asia]]), 35 million in the South American Andes, and 0.3 million in [[Colorado]] [[Rocky Mountains]].<ref name=hor>{{cite book|vauthors=Hornbein T, Schoene R |year=2001|title=High Altitude: An Exploration of Human Adaptation (Lung Biology in Health and Disease Volume 161)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P1clQRmZk1AC&printsec |publisher=Marcel Dekker, New York, USA |pages=42–874 |isbn=082474604X}}</ref> Certain natives of Tibet, Ethiopia, and the Andes have been living at these high altitudes for generations and are protected from hypoxia as a consequence of genetic adaptation.<ref name=moor/><ref name=pen /> It is estimated that at {{convert|4000|m|ft}}, every [[lung volumes|lungful of air]] only has 60% of the oxygen molecules that people at sea level have.<ref name=hor /> At elevations above {{convert|7600|m|ft}}, [[hypoxia (medical)|lack of oxygen]] becomes seriously lethal. That is, these highlanders are constantly exposed to an intolerably low oxygen environment, yet they live without any debilitating problems.<ref name=mue/> Basically, the shared adaptation is the ability to maintain relatively low levels of [[haemoglobin]], which is the [[protein|chemical complex]] for [[circulatory system|transporting oxygen in the blood]].<ref name=moo /> One of the best documented effects of high altitude is a progressive reduction in [[birth weight]]. It has been known that women of long-resident high-altitude population are not affected. These women are known to give birth to heavier-weight infants than women of lowland inhabitants. This is particularly true among Tibetan babies, whose average birth weight is 294-650 (~470) g heavier than the surrounding [[chinese people|Chinese population]]; and their [[oxygen saturation|blood-oxygen level]] is considerably higher.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Niermeyer S, Yang P, Shanmina, Drolkar, Zhuang J, Moore LG|year=1995 |title=Arterial oxygen saturation in Tibetan and Han infants born in Lhasa, Tibet| url=http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199511093331903 |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=333 |issue=9 |pages=1248–1252|pmid=7566001|doi=10.1056/NEJM199511093331903 }}</ref>
The first scientific investigations of high-altitude adaptation was done by [[A. Roberto Frisancho]] of the [[University of Michigan]] in the late 1960s among the [[Quechua people]] of Peru.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Frisancho AR |title=Human growth and pulmonary function of a high altitude Peruvian Quechua population |journal=Hum Biol |volume= 41|issue=3 | pages=365–379 |year=1969 |pmid=5372293|jstor=41435777 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Leonard WR |title=Contributions of A. Roberto Frisancho to human population biology: An introduction |journal=American Journal of Human Biology |volume=21 |issue=5 | pages=599–605 |year=2009 |pmid=19367580|doi=10.1002/ajhb.20916}}</ref> [[Paul T. Baker]], [[Pennsylvania State University|Penn State University]], (in the [http://anth.la.psu.edu/ Department of Anthropology]) also conducted a considerable amount of research into human adaptation to high altitudes, and mentored students who continued this research.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/member-directory/deceased-members/58048.html|title=Paul Baker|last=http://www.nasonline.org|first=National Academy of Sciences -|website=www.nasonline.org|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref> One of these students went on to conduct research on high altitude adaptation among the Tibetans in the early 1980s through to today, anthropologist [[Cynthia Beall]] of the [[Case Western Reserve University]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Beall C |title=Human adaptability studies at high altitude: Research designs and major concepts during fifty years of discovery |journal=Am J Hum Biol |volume=25|issue=2 | pages=141–147 |year=2013 |pmid=23349118 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.22355}}</ref>
==Physiological basis==
===Tibetans=== [[File:Sherpa.jpg|200px|thumb|right| A Sherpa family]]
Scientists started to notice the extraordinary physical performance of Tibetans since the beginning of Himalayan climbing era in the early 20th century. The hypothesis of a possible evolutionary genetic adaptation makes sense.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Wu T, Kayser B |title=High altitude adaptation in Tibetans |journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=7 |issue=3 | pages=193–208 |year=2006 |pmid=16978132 |doi=10.1089/ham.2006.7.193|last2=Kayser }}</ref> The [[Tibetan plateau]] has an average elevation of {{convert|4000|m|ft}} above sea level, and covering more than 2.5 million km, it is the highest and largest [[plateau]] in the world. In 1990, it was estimated that 4,594,188 Tibetans live on the plateau, with 53% living at an altitude over {{convert|3500|m|ft}}. Fairly large numbers (about 600,000) live at an altitude exceeding {{convert|4500|m|ft}} in the Chantong-Qingnan area.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Wu T|year=2001 |title=The Qinghai-Tibetan plateau: how high do Tibetans live?| journal=High Alt Med Biol|volume=2|issue=4 |pages=489–499|pmid=11809089 |doi=10.1089/152702901753397054}}</ref> Where the Tibetan highlanders live, the oxygen level is only about 60% of that at sea level. The Tibetans, who have been living in this region for 3,000 years, do not exhibit the elevated haemoglobin concentrations to cope with oxygen deficiency as observed in other populations who have moved temporarily or permanently at high altitudes. Instead, the Tibetans inhale more air with each breath and breathe more rapidly than either sea-level populations or Andeans. Tibetans have better [[oxygenation (medical)|oxygenation]] at birth, enlarged lung volumes throughout life, and a higher capacity for [[physical exercise|exercise]]. They show a sustained increase in [[brain|cerebral]] blood flow, lower haemoglobin concentration, and less susceptibility to [[chronic mountain sickness]] than other populations, due to their longer history of high-altitude habitation.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Moore LG, Niermeyer S, Zamudio S |year=1998 |title=Human adaptation to high altitude: Regional and life-cycle perspectives |journal=Am J Phys Anthropol |volume=107 |pages=25–64 |pmid=9881522 | doi=10.1002/(SICI)1096-8644(1998)107:27+<25::AID-AJPA3>3.0.CO;2-L |last2=Niermeyer |last3=Zamudio}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=Lorna G|last=Moore |year=2001 |title=Human genetic adaptation to high altitude|journal=High Altitude Medicine & Biology |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=257–279 |pmid=11443005| doi=10.1089/152702901750265341}}</ref>
General people can develop short-term tolerance with careful physical preparation and systematic monitoring of movements, but the biological changes are quite temporary and reversible when they return to lowlands.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Muza SR, Beidleman BA, Fulco CS|year=2010 |title=Altitude preexposure recommendations for inducing acclimatization| journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=11|issue=2|pages=87–92|pmid=20586592 |doi=10.1089/ham.2010.1006 |last2=Beidleman |last3=Fulco }}</ref> Moreover, unlike lowland people who only experience [[hyperventilation|increased breathing]] for a few days after entering high altitudes, Tibetans retain this rapid breathing and elevated lung-capacity throughout their lifetime.<ref name=beall07>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM |year=2007 |title=Two routes to functional adaptation: Tibetan and Andean high-altitude natives | journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A|volume=14|issue=Suppl 1 |pages=8655–8660|pmid=17494744 |pmc=1876443 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0701985104|bibcode=2007PNAS..104.8655B }}</ref> This enables them to inhale larger amounts of air per unit of time to compensate for low oxygen levels. In addition, they have high levels (mostly double) of [[nitric oxide]] in their blood, when compared to lowlanders, and this probably helps their blood vessels [[vasodilation|dilate]] for enhanced [[blood circulation]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM, Laskowski D, Erzurum SC|year=2012 |title=Nitric oxide in adaptation to altitude |journal=Free Radic Biol Med |volume=52 |issue=7 |pages=1123–1134 |pmid=22300645 |pmc=3295887 |doi=10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2011.12.028|last2=Laskowski |last3=Erzurum }}</ref> Further, their haemoglobin level is not significantly different (average 15.6 g/dl in males and 14.2 g/dl in females),<ref name=beall1998>{{cite journal|last1=Beall|first1=Cynthia M.|last2=Brittenham|first2=Gary M.|last3=Strohl|first3=Kingman P.|last4=Blangero|first4=John|last5=Williams-Blangero|first5=Sarah|last6=Goldstein|first6=Melvyn C.|last7=Decker|first7=Michael J.|last8=Vargas|first8=Enrique|last9=Villena|first9=Mercedes|last10=Soria|first10=Rudy|last11=Alarcon|first11=Ana Maria|last12=Gonzales|first12=Cristina|display-authors=8|title=Hemoglobin concentration of high-altitude Tibetans and Bolivian Aymara|journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology|date=1998|volume=106|issue=3|pages=385–400|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1096-8644(199807)106:3<385::AID-AJPA10>3.0.CO;2-X|pmid=9696153}}</ref> from those of people living at low altitude. (Normally, mountaineers experience >2 g/dl increase in Hb level at Mt. Everest base camp in two weeks.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Windsor|first1=J. S|last2=Rodway|first2=G. W |title=Heights and haematology: the story of haemoglobin at altitude |journal=Postgraduate Medical Journal |date=2007 |volume=83 |issue=977 |pages=148–151 |doi=10.1136/pgmj.2006.049734 |pmid=17344565 |pmc=2599997}}</ref>) In this way they are able to evade both the effects of hypoxia and mountain sickness throughout life. Even when they climbed the highest summits like Mt. Everest, they showed regular oxygen uptake, greater ventilation, more brisk hypoxic ventilatory responses, larger lung volumes, greater diffusing capacities, constant body weight and a better quality of sleep, compared to people from the lowland.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Wu T, Li S, Ward MP |year=2005 |title=Tibetans at extreme altitude| journal=Wilderness Environ Med |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=47–54 |pmid=15813148 |doi=10.1580/pr04-04.1|last2=Li |last3=Ward }}</ref>
===Andeans===
In contrast to the Tibetans, the Andean highlanders, who have been living at high-altitudes for no more than 11,000 years, show different pattern of haemoglobin adaptation. Their haemoglobin concentration is higher compared to those of lowlander population, which also happens to lowlanders moving to high altitude. When they spend some weeks in the lowland their haemoglobin drops to average of other people. This shows only temporary and reversible acclimatisation. However, in contrast to lowland people, they do have increased oxygen level in their haemoglobin, that is, more oxygen per blood volume than other people. This confers an ability to carry more oxygen in each red blood cell, making a more effective transport of oxygen in their body, while their breathing is essentially at the same rate.<ref name=beall07 /> This enables them to overcome hypoxia and normally reproduce without risk of death for the mother or baby. The Andean highlanders are known from the 16th-century missionaries that their reproduction had always been normal, without any effect in the [[fecundity|giving birth]] or the risk for early pregnancy loss, which are common to hypoxic stress.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vitzthum |first1=Virginia J. |title=Fifty fertile years: anthropologists' studies of reproduction in high altitude natives |journal=American Journal of Human Biology |year=2013 |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=179–189 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.22357 |pmid=23382088}}</ref> They have developmentally acquired enlarged residual lung volume and its associated increase in [[alveolus|alveolar]] area, which are supplemented with increased tissue thickness and moderate increase in [[red blood cells]]. Though the physical growth in body size is [[stunted growth|delayed]], growth in lung volumes is accelerated.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Frisancho|first1=A. Roberto|title=Developmental functional adaptation to high altitude: review|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|date=2013|volume=25|issue=2|pages=151–168|doi=10.1002/ajhb.22367|pmid=24065360}}</ref> An incomplete adaptation such as elevated haemoglobin levels still leaves them at risk for mountain sickness with old age. [[File:QuechuaWoman.jpg|thumb|left| Quechua woman with llamas]] Among the Quechua people of the [[Altiplano]], there is a significant variation in ''[[NOS3]]'' (the gene encoding [[endothelial nitric oxide synthase]], eNOS), which is associated with higher levels of nitric oxide in high altitude.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Wang|first1=Pei|last2=Ha|first2=Alice Y.N. |last3=Kidd|first3=Kenneth K. |last4=Koehle |first4=Michael S. |last5=Rupert|first5=Jim L. |title=A variant of the endothelial nitric oxide synthase gene (NOS3)associated with AMS susceptibility is less common in the Quechua, a high altitude Native population|journal=High Altitude Medicine & Biology|year=2010|volume=11|issue=1|pages=27–30|doi=10.1089/ham.2009.1054|pmid=20367485}}</ref> Nuñoa children of Quechua ancestry exhibit higher blood-oxygen content (91.3) and lower heart rate (84.8) than their counterpart school children of different ethnicity, who have an average of 89.9 blood-oxygen and 88-91 heart rate.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Huicho L, Pawson IG, León-Velarde F, Rivera-Chira M, Pacheco A, Muro M, Silva J|year=2001 |title=Oxygen saturation and heart rate in healthy school children and adolescents living at high altitude| journal=Am J Hum Biol|volume=13 |issue=6 |pages=761–770|pmid=11748815 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.1122|last2=Pawson |last3=León-Velarde |last4=Rivera-Chira |last5=Pacheco |last6=Muro |last7=Silva }}</ref> High-altitude born and bred females of Quechua origins have comparatively enlarged lung volume for increased respiration.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Kiyamu M, Bigham A, Parra E, León-Velarde F, Rivera-Chira M, Brutsaert TD|year=2012 |title=Developmental and genetic components explain enhanced pulmonary volumes of female Peruvian Quechua| journal=Am J Phys Anthropol|volume=148 |issue=4 |pages=534–542|pmid=22552823 |doi=10.1002/ajpa.22069|last2=Bigham |last3=Parra |last4=León-Velarde |last5=Rivera-Chira |last6=Brutsaert }}</ref> [[File:Aymara ceremony copacabana 4.jpg|240px|thumb|right| Aymara ceremony]] [[haematology|Blood profile]] comparisons show that among the Andeans, [[Aymara people|Aymaran highlanders]] are better adapted to highlands than the Quechuas.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Arnaud J, Quilici JC, Rivière G|year=1981 |title=High-altitude haematology: Quechua-Aymara comparisons| journal=Annals of Human Biology|volume=8 |issue=6 |pages=573–578|pmid=7337418 |doi=10.1080/03014468100005421|last2=Quilici |last3=Rivière }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Arnaud J, Gutierrez N, Tellez W, Vergnes H|year=1985 |title=Haematology and erythrocyte metabolism in man at high altitude: an Aymara-Quechua comparison| journal=Am J Phys Anthropol|volume=67 |issue=3 |pages=279–284|pmid=4061583 |doi=10.1002/ajpa.1330670313|last2=Gutierrez |last3=Tellez |last4=Vergnes }}</ref> Among the [[bolivian people|Bolivian]] Aymara people, the resting ventilation and hypoxic ventilatory response were quite low (roughly 1.5 times lower), in contrast to those of the Tibetans. The intrapopulation genetic variation was relatively less among the Aymara people.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM, Strohl KP, Blangero J, Williams-Blangero S, Almasy LA, Decker MJ, Worthman CM, Goldstein MC, Vargas E, Villena M, Soria R, Alarcon AM, Gonzales C |year=1997 |title=Ventilation and hypoxic ventilatory response of Tibetan and Aymara high altitude natives |journal=Am J Phys Anthropol |volume=104 |issue=4| pages=427–447 |pmid=9453694 |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1096-8644(199712)104:4<427::AID-AJPA1>3.0.CO;2-P |last2=Strohl |last3=Blangero|last4=Williams-Blangero |last5=Almasy |last6=Decker |last7=Worthman |last8=Goldstein |last9=Vargas |last10=Villena |last11=Soria|last12=Alarcon|last13=Gonzales }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Beall CM |year=2007|title=Tibetan and Andean contrasts in adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia |journal=Adv Exp Med Biol |volume=475 |issue=1 |pages=63–74 |pmid=10849649|doi=}}</ref> Moreover, unlike the Tibetans, the blood haemoglobin level is quite normal among Aymarans, with an average of 19.2 g/dl for males and 17.8 g/dl for females.<ref name=beall1998/> Among the different native highlander populations, the underlying physiological responses to adaptation are quite different. For example, among four quantitative features, such as are resting ventilation, hypoxic ventilatory response, oxygen saturation, and haemoglobin concentration, the levels of variations are significantly different between the Tibetans and the Aymaras.<ref name=bea00>{{cite journal| author=Beall CM |year=2000 |title=Tibetan and Andean patterns of adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia|journal=Hum Biol|volume=72 |issue=1 |pages=201–228 |pmid=10721618|doi=}}</ref> The Andeans, in general are the most poorly adapted, as particularly shown by their frequent mountain sickness and loss of adaptative characters when they move to lowlands.<ref>{{cite journal| author=Xing G, Qualls C, Huicho L, Rivera-Ch M, Stobdan T, Slessarev M, Prisman E, Ito S, Wu H, Norboo A, Dolma D, Kunzang M, Norboo T, Gamboa JL, Claydon VE, Fisher J, Zenebe G, Gebremedhin A, Hainsworth R, Verma A, Appenzeller O|year=2008 |title=Adaptation and mal-adaptation to ambient hypoxia; Andean, Ethiopian and Himalayan patterns|url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0002342 |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=3 |issue=6 |pages=e2342 |pmid=18523639 |pmc=2396283 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0002342|last2=Qualls |last3=Huicho |last4=Rivera-Ch |last5=Stobdan |last6=Slessarev |last7=Prisman |last8=Ito |last9=Wu |last10=Norboo |last11=Dolma |last12=Kunzang |last13=Norboo |last14=Gamboa |last15=Claydon |last16=Fisher |last17=Zenebe |last18=Gebremedhin |last19=Hainsworth |last20=Verma |last21=Appenzeller |bibcode=2008PLoSO...3.2342X }}</ref>
===Ethiopians===
The peoples of the [[Ethiopian highlands]] also live at extremely high altitudes, around {{convert|3000|m|ft}} to {{convert|3500|m|ft}}. Highland Ethiopians exhibit elevated haemoglobin levels, like Andeans and lowlander peoples at high altitudes, but do not exhibit the Andean’s increased in oxygen-content of haemoglobin.<ref>{{cite journal| author =Beall CM |year=2006|title=Andean, Tibetan, and Ethiopian patterns of adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia |journal=Integr Comp Biol |volume=46 |issue=1 |pages=18–24 |pmid=21672719 |doi=10.1093/icb/icj004}}</ref> Among healthy individuals, the average haemoglobin concentrations are 15.9 and 15.0 g/dl for males and females respectively (which is lower than normal, almost similar to the Tibetans), and an average oxygen saturation of haemoglobin is 95.3% (which is higher than average, like the Andeans).<ref>{{cite journal| author=Beall CM, Decker MJ, Brittenham GM, Kushner I, Gebremedhin A, Strohl KP |year=2002 |title=An Ethiopian pattern of human adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia |journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A |volume=99 |issue=26 |pages=17215–17218 |pmid=12471159 |pmc=139295 |doi=10.1073/pnas.252649199 |last2=Decker |last3=Brittenham |last4=Kushner |last5=Gebremedhin |last6=Strohl |bibcode=2002PNAS...9917215B}}</ref> Additionally, Ethiopian highlanders do not exhibit any significant change in blood circulation of the brain, which has been observed among the Peruvian highlanders (and attributed to their frequent altitude-related illnesses).<ref>{{cite journal| author=Claydon VE, Gulli G, Slessarev M, Appenzeller O, Zenebe G, Gebremedhin A, Hainsworth R |year=2008|title=Cerebrovascular responses to hypoxia and hypocapnia in Ethiopian high altitude dwellers |journal=Stroke |volume=39 |issue=2|pages=336–342 |pmid=18096845 |doi=10.1161/STROKEAHA.107.491498|last2=Gulli|last3=Slessarev|last4=Appenzeller|last5=Zenebe|last6=Gebremedhin|last7=Hainsworth}}</ref> Yet, similar to the Andeans and Tibetans, the Ethiopian highlanders are immune to the extreme dangers posed by high-altitude environment, and their pattern of adaptation is definitely unique from that of other highland peoples.<ref name=hor />
==Genetic basis==
The underlying [[molecular evolution]] of high-altitude adaptation has been explored and understood fairly recently.<ref name=mue /> Depending on the geographical and environmental pressures, high-altitude adaptation involves different genetic patterns, some of which have evolved quite recently. For example, Tibetan adaptations became prevalent in the past 3,000 years, a rapid example of [[recent human evolution]]. At the turn of the 21st century, it was reported that the genetic make-up of the respiratory components of the Tibetan and the Ethiopian populations are significantly different.<ref name=bea00 />
=== Tibetans ===
Substantial evidence in Tibetan highlanders suggests that variation in haemoglobin and [[oxygen saturation|blood-oxygen]] levels are adaptive as [[Fitness (biology)|Darwinian fitness]]. It has been documented that Tibetan women with a high likelihood of possessing one to two [[allele]]s for high blood-oxygen content (which is odd for normal women) had more surviving children; the higher the oxygen capacity, the lower the infant mortality.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Beall CM, Song K, Elston RC, Goldstein MC |year=2004 |title=Higher offspring survival among Tibetan women with high oxygen saturation genotypes residing at {{convert|4000|m|ft}}| url=http://www.pnas.org/content/101/39/14300 |journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A |volume=101|issue=39 |pages=14300–14304 |pmid=15353580|pmc=521103 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0405949101|last2=Song |last3=Elston |last4=Goldstein |bibcode=2004PNAS..10114300B }}</ref> In 2010, for the first time, the genes responsible for the unique adaptive traits were identified following genome sequences of 50 Tibetans and 40 [[Han Chinese]] from [[Beijing]]. Initially, the strongest signal of natural selection detected was a transcription factor involved in response to hypoxia, called endothelial Per-Arnt-Sim (PAS) domain protein 1 (''[[EPAS1]]''). It was found that one [[single-nucleotide polymorphism]] (SNP) at ''EPAS1'' shows a 78% frequency difference between Tibetan and mainland Chinese samples, representing the fastest genetic change observed in any human gene to date. Hence, Tibetan adaptation to high altitude becomes the fastest process of [[phenotype|phenotypically observable]] evolution in humans,<ref>{{cite web|author1=Native Village Youth |author2=Education news |title=Tibetans evolved at fastest pace ever measured |url=http://www.nativevillage.org/Archives/2011%20Archives/MAY%202011%20News/Tibetans%20Evolved%20at%20Fastest%20Pace%20Ever%20Measured.htm | date=May 2011|accessdate=2013-04-15}}</ref> which is estimated to occur in less than 3,000 years ago, when the Tibetans split up from the mainland Chinese population.<ref name=yi /> [[Mutations]] in ''EPAS1'', at higher frequency in Tibetans than their Han neighbours, correlate with decreased haemoglobin concentrations among the Tibetans, which is the hallmark of their adaptation to hypoxia. Simultaneously, two genes, egl nine homolog 1 (''[[EGLN1]]'') (which inhibits haemoglobin production under high oxygen concentration) and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (''[[PPARA]]''), were also identified to be positively selected in relation to decreased haemoglobin nature in the Tibetans.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Simonson TS, Yang Y, Huff CD, Yun H, Qin G, Witherspoon DJ, Bai Z, Lorenzo FR, Xing J, Jorde LB, Prchal JT, Ge R |year=2010 |title=Genetic evidence for high-altitude adaptation in Tibet | url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/329/5987/72 |journal=Science |volume=329 |issue=5987|pages=72–75 |pmid=20466884 |doi=10.1126/science.1189406|last2=Yang |last3=Huff |last4=Yun |last5=Qin |last6=Witherspoon |last7=Bai |last8=Lorenzo |last9=Xing |last10=Jorde |last11=Prchal |last12=Ge |bibcode=2010Sci...329...72S }}</ref>
Similarly, the [[Sherpas]], known for their Himalayan hardiness, exhibit similar patterns in the ''EPAS1'' gene, which further fortifies that the gene is under [[Selection (biology)|selection]] for adaptation to the high-altitude life of Tibetans.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Hanaoka M, Droma Y, Basnyat B, Ito M, Kobayashi N, Katsuyama Y, Kubo K, Ota M |year=2012 |title=Genetic variants in EPAS1 contribute to adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia in Sherpas | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0050566 |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7 |issue=12|pages=e50566|pmid=23227185 |pmc=3515610|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0050566|last2=Droma |last3=Basnyat |last4=Ito |last5=Kobayashi |last6=Katsuyama |last7=Kubo |last8=Ota |bibcode=2012PLoSO...750566H }}</ref> A study in 2014 indicates that the mutant ''[[EPAS1]]'' gene could have been inherited from archaic [[hominin]]s, the [[Denisovans]].<ref name="Huerta-Sanchez et al. 2014">{{cite journal |last1=Huerta-Sánchez|first1=Emilia |last2=Jin |first2=Xin |last3=Asan |last4=Bianba |first4=Zhuoma|last5=Peter|first5=Benjamin M. |last6=Vinckenbosch|first6=Nicolas|last7=Liang|first7=Yu|last8=Yi|first8=Xin|last9=He|first9=Mingze|last10=Somel|first10=Mehmet|last11=Ni|first11=Peixiang|last12=Wang|first12=Bo|last13=Ou|first13=Xiaohua|last14=Huasang|last15=Luosang|first15=Jiangbai|last16=Cuo|first16=Zha Xi Ping |last17=Li |first17=Kui |last18=Gao |first18=Guoyi |last19=Yin |first19=Ye |last20=Wang|first20=Wei |last21=Zhang |first21=Xiuqing |last22=Xu |first22=Xun|last23=Yang |first23=Huanming |last24=Li |first24=Yingrui |last25=Wang |first25=Jian |last26=Wang |first26=Jun |last27=Nielsen |first27=Rasmus |title=Altitude adaptation in Tibetans caused by introgression of Denisovan-like DNA |journal=Nature |date=2014 |volume=512 |issue=7513 |pages=194–197 |doi=10.1038/nature13408 |pmid=25043035 |bibcode=2014Natur.512..194H |display-authors=8 |pmc=4134395}}</ref> ''EPAS1'' and ''EGLN1'' are definitely the major genes for unique adaptive traits when compared with those of the Chinese and Japanese.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Peng Y, Yang Z, Zhang H, Cui C, Qi X, Luo X, Tao X, Wu T, Ouzhuluobu, Basang, Ciwangsangbu, Danzengduojie, Chen H, Shi H, Su B|year=2011 |title=Genetic variations in Tibetan populations and high-altitude adaptation at the Himalayas | url=http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/28/2/1075.full |journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution |volume=28|issue=2|pages=1075–81|pmid=21030426 |doi=10.1093/molbev/msq290|last2=Yang |last3=Zhang |last4=Cui |last5=Qi |last6=Luo |last7=Tao |last8=Wu |last13=Chen |last14=Shi |last15=Su }}</ref> Comparative genome analysis in 2014 revealed that the Tibetans inherited an equal mixture of genomes from the Nepalese-Sherpas and Hans, and they acquired the adaptive genes from the sherpa-lineage. Further, the population split was estimated to occur around 20,000 to 40,000 years ago, a range of which support archaeological, mitochondria DNA and Y chromosome evidence for an initial colonisation of the Tibetan plateau around 30,000 years ago.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jeong |first1=Choongwon |last2=Alkorta-Aranburu |first2=Gorka |last3=Basnyat |first3=Buddha |last4=Neupane|first4=Maniraj |last5=Witonsky |first5=David B. |last6=Pritchard|first6=Jonathan K. |last7=Beall |first7=Cynthia M. |last8=Di Rienzo|first8=Anna |title=Admixture facilitates genetic adaptations to high altitude in Tibet|journal=Nature Communications |year=2014 |volume=5 |issue=3281 |doi=10.1038/ncomms4281|pmid=24513612|pages=3281|bibcode=2014NatCo...5E3281J}}</ref>
The genes (''EPAS1'', ''EGLN1'', and ''PPARA'') function in concert with another gene named [[hypoxia inducible factors]] (''HIF''), which in turn is a principal regulator of red blood cell production ([[erythropoiesis]]) in response to oxygen metabolism.<ref>{{cite journal |author=MacInnis MJ, Rupert JL |year=2011 |title='ome on the Range: altitude adaptation, positive selection, and Himalayan genomics | journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=12 |issue=2 |pages=133–139|pmid=21718161 |doi=10.1089/ham.2010.1090|last2=Rupert }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=van Patot MC, Gassmann M |year=2011 |title=Hypoxia: adapting to high altitude by mutating EPAS-1, the gene encoding HIF-2α | journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=12|issue=2|pages=157–167|pmid=21718164 |doi=10.1089/ham.2010.1099|last2=Gassmann }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Simonson TS, McClain DA, Jorde LB, Prchal JT |year=2012 |title=Genetic determinants of Tibetan high-altitude adaptation | journal=Human Genetics |volume=131|issue=4|pages=527–533|pmid=22068265 |doi=10.1007/s00439-011-1109-3|last2=McClain |last3=Jorde |last4=Prchal }}</ref> The genes are associated not only with decreased haemoglobin levels, but also in regulating energy metabolism. ''EPAS1'' is significantly associated with increased lactate concentration (the product of [[anaerobic glycolysis]]), and ''PPARA'' is correlated with decrease in the activity of [[fatty acid oxidation]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ge RL, Simonson TS, Cooksey RC, Tanna U, Qin G, Huff CD, Witherspoon DJ, Xing J, Zhengzhong B, Prchal JT, Jorde LB, McClain DA |year=2012 |title=Metabolic insight into mechanisms of high-altitude adaptation in Tibetans | journal=Mol Genet Metab |volume=106|issue=2|pages=244–247 |pmid=22503288 |pmc=3437309 |doi=10.1016/j.ymgme.2012.03.003 |last2=Simonson |last3=Cooksey |last4=Tanna |last5=Qin |last6=Huff |last7=Witherspoon |last8=Xing |last9=Zhengzhong |last10=Prchal |last11=Jorde |last12=McClain }}</ref> ''EGLN1'' codes for an enzyme, prolyl hydroxylase 2 (PHD2), involved in erythropoiesis. Among the Tibetans, mutation in ''EGLN1'' (specifically at position 12, where cytosine is replaced with guanine; and at 380, where G is replaced with C) results in mutant PHD2 (aspartic acid at position 4 becomes glutamine, and cysteine at 127 becomes serine) and this mutation inhibits erythropoiesis. The mutation is estimated to occur about 8,000 years ago.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lorenzo|first1=Felipe R|last2=Huff|first2=Chad|last3=Myllymäki|first3=Mikko|last4=Olenchock|first4=Benjamin|last5=Swierczek|first5=Sabina|last6=Tashi|first6=Tsewang|last7=Gordeuk|first7=Victor|last8=Wuren|first8=Tana|last9=Ri-Li|first9=Ge|last10=McClain|first10=Donald A|last11=Khan|first11=Tahsin M|last12=Koul|first12=Parvaiz A|last13=Guchhait|first13=Prasenjit|last14=Salama|first14=Mohamed E|last15=Xing|first15=Jinchuan|last16=Semenza|first16=Gregg L|last17=Liberzon|first17=Ella|last18=Wilson|first18=Andrew|last19=Simonson|first19=Tatum S|last20=Jorde|first20=Lynn B|last21=Kaelin|first21=William G|last22=Koivunen|first22=Peppi|last23=Prchal|first23=Josef T|title=A genetic mechanism for Tibetan high-altitude adaptation|journal=Nature Genetics|year=2014|volume=46|doi=10.1038/ng.3067|pmid=25129147|issue=9|pages=951–6|pmc=4473257}}</ref> Further, the Tibetans are enriched for genes in the disease class of human reproduction (such as genes from the ''[[DAZ associated protein 1|DAZ]]'', ''[[BPY2]]'', ''[[CDY1|CDY]]'', and ''[[HLA-DQ]]'' and ''[[HLA-DR]]'' gene clusters) and biological process categories of response to [[DNA damage]] stimulus and [[DNA repair]] (such as ''[[RAD51]]'', ''[[RAD52]]'', and ''[[MRE11A]]''), which are related to the adaptive traits of high infant birth weight and [[melanism|darker skin tone]] and are most likely due to recent local adaptation.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Zhang YB, Li X, Zhang F, Wang DM, Yu J|year=2012 |title=A preliminary study of copy number variation in Tibetans | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0041768 |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7|issue=7|pages=e41768|pmid=22844521| pmc=3402393 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0041768|last2=Li |last3=Zhang |last4=Wang |last5=Yu |bibcode=2012PLoSO...741768Z }}</ref>
===Andeans===
The patterns of genetic adaptation among the Andeans are largely distinct from those of the Tibetan, with both populations showing evidence of positive natural selection in different genes or gene regions. However, ''EGLN1'' appears to be the principal signature of evolution, as it shows evidence of positive selection in both Tibetans and Andeans. Even then, the pattern of variation for this gene differs between the two populations.<ref name=bigh /> Among the Andeans, there are no significant associations between ''EPAS1'' or ''EGLN1'' SNP [[genotype]]s and haemoglobin concentration, which has been the characteristic of the Tibetans.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Bigham AW, Wilson MJ, Julian CG, Kiyamu M, Vargas E, Leon-Velarde F, Rivera-Chira M, Rodriquez C, Browne VA, Parra E, Brutsaert TD, Moore LG, Shriver MD |year=2013 |title=Andean and Tibetan patterns of adaptation to high altitude | journal=Am J Hum Biol|volume=25|issue=2|pages=190–197|pmid=23348729 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.22358|last2=Wilson |last3=Julian |last4=Kiyamu |last5=Vargas |last6=Leon-Velarde |last7=Rivera-Chira |last8=Rodriquez |last9=Browne |last10=Parra |last11=Brutsaert |last12=Moore |last13=Shriver }}</ref> The whole genome sequences of 20 Andeans (half of them having chronic mountain sickness) revealed that two genes, SENP1 (an erythropoiesis regulator) and ANP32D (an oncogene) play vital roles in their weak adaptation to hypoxia.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Zhou D, Udpa N, Ronen R, Stobdan T, Liang J, Appenzeller O, Zhao HW, Yin Y, Du Y, Guo L, Cao R, Wang Y, Jin X, Huang C, Jia W, Cao D, Guo G, Gamboa JL, Villafuerte F, Callacondo D, Xue J, Liu S, Frazer KA, Li Y, Bafna V, Haddad GG |title=Whole-genome sequencing uncovers the genetic basis of chronic mountain sickness in Andean highlanders |journal=Am J Hum Genet |volume=93|issue=S0002–9297(13)00331–5 | pages=452–62|year=2013 |pmid=23954164 |pmc=3769925 |doi=10.1016/j.ajhg.2013.07.011|last2=Udpa |last3=Ronen |last4=Stobdan |last5=Liang |last6=Appenzeller |last7=Zhao |last8=Yin |last9=Du |last10=Guo |last11=Cao |last12=Wang |last13=Jin |last14=Huang |last15=Jia |last16=Cao |last17=Guo |last18=Gamboa |last19=Villafuerte |last20=Callacondo |last21=Xue |last22=Liu |last23=Frazer |last24=Li |last25=Bafna |last26=Haddad }}</ref>
===Ethiopians===
The adaptive mechanism of Ethiopian highlanders is quite different. This is probably because their migration to the highland was relatively early; for example, the [[amhara people|Amhara]] have inhabited altitudes above {{convert|2500|m|ft}} for at least 5,000 years and altitudes around {{convert|2000|m|ft}} to {{convert|2400|m|ft}} for more than 70,000 years.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2006|title=Human technical behavior in the African Middle Stone Age: The lithic assemblange of Porc-Epic Cave (Dire Dawa, Ethiopia)|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10437-006-9000-7|journal=African Archaeological Review|volume=22|issue=4|pages=177–197|doi=10.1007/s10437-006-9000-7|pmid=|author=Pleurdeau D}}</ref> Genomic analysis of two ethnic groups, Amhara and [[oromo people|Oromo]], revealed that gene variations associated with haemoglobin difference among Tibetans or other variants at the same [[locus (genetics)|gene location]] do not influence the adaptation in Ethiopians.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Alkorta-Aranburu G, Beall CM, Witonsky DB, Gebremedhin A, Pritchard JK, Di Rienzo A|year=2012 |title=The genetic architecture of adaptations to high altitude in Ethiopia | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1003110 |journal=PLOS Genetics |volume=8|issue=12|pages=e1003110|pmid=23236293| pmc=3516565 |doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1003110|last2=Beall |last3=Witonsky |last4=Gebremedhin |last5=Pritchard |last6=Di Rienzo }}</ref> Identification of specific genes further reveals that several candidate genes are involved in Ethiopians, including ''[[CBARA1]]'', ''[[VAV3]]'', ''[[ARNT2]]'' and ''[[THRB]]''. Two of these genes (''THRB'' and ''ARNT2'') are known to play a role in the [[Hypoxia-inducible factors|HIF-1 pathway]], a pathway implicated in previous work reported in Tibetan and Andean studies. This supports the concept that adaptation to high altitude arose independently among different highlanders as a result of [[convergent evolution]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Scheinfeldt LB, Soi S, Thompson S, Ranciaro A, Woldemeskel D, Beggs W, Lambert C, Jarvis JP, Abate D, Belay G, Tishkoff SA|year=2012 |title=Genetic adaptation to high altitude in the Ethiopian highlands | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1003110 |journal=Genome Biol |volume=13|issue=1|pages=R1 |pmid=22264333| pmc=3334582 |doi=10.1186/gb-2012-13-1-r1|last2=Soi |last3=Thompson |last4=Ranciaro |last5=Woldemeskel |last6=Beggs |last7=Lambert |last8=Jarvis |last9=Abate |last10=Belay |last11=Tishkoff }}</ref>

{{about|the approach developed by Roy Harris|the approach based on Hans-Heinrich Lieb's work|Integrational linguistics}} '''Integrationism''' (also known as '''integrational linguistics''') is an approach in the [[theory of communication]] that emphasizes innovative participation by communicators within contexts and rejects rule-based models of language. It was developed by a group of [[linguists]] at the [[University of Oxford]] during the 1980s, notably [[Roy Harris (linguist)|Roy Harris]].
The International Association for the Integrational Study of Language and Communication was founded in 1998 and has members in more than twenty-five countries around the world.<ref>[http://www.integrationists.com IAISLC].</ref>
==Integrationism and language== While the integrationist views of [[Roy Harris|Harris]] and Dr Adrian Pablé, among others, differ from those who believe that cognition is [[Distributed cognition|distributed]] (i.e. Kravchenko and Love), the view on language between the two fields are quite similar. Both sides criticize the traditional view of linguistics which holds language as an individual internal psychological concern that takes written language as the base from which to begin analysis. Instead, integrationists view knowledge (which includes language) as “(i) linked to an individual’s experience, and therefore dependent on the ‘evidence available’ to that particular individual, but at the same time (ii) unpredictable because any integrational task involving sign-making and sign-interpreting is carried out in actual, time-embedded situations, which are not simply ‘given’, either.”.<ref name=pable2010>Pablé, 2010.{{clarify|date=April 2015}}</ref> In other words, language usage is intrinsically, and without fail, contextual in all of its uses. Furthermore, Pablé, Haas & Christe<ref name=phc2010>Pablé, Haas & Christe, 2010.</ref> question whether language is even amenable to scientific description, based upon its contextual nature. The contextual nature of language leads to a rejection of the notion that language is a ‘fixed code’. Harris discusses this extensively:
:"When we come across words we do not know, words which apparently did not exist a few years ago, it is difficult to resist two conclusions. One is that if there are verbal ‘codes’, they cannot be fixed: on the contrary, they must be changing all the time. The other conclusion is that if there are such codes, different people use different ones, and these too change. Until yesterday, mine did not include the word moshpit: today it does. But if the code has the kind of instability evidenced by the sudden emergence of new words and meanings, what guarantee of stability is there for ‘old’ words and meanings? The integrationist sees none. And if indeed there is none, then it is the viability of the concept of the code that is itself called in question. For it conspicuously fails to fulfill the theoretical function that is required of a code in semantics; namely to provide a source for those publicly invariant meanings that supposedly underpin verbal communication in the community, and can consequently be both ‘encoded’ and ‘decoded’ by those who know the code.”<ref>Harris, 1998.</ref>
Instead of parts of a fixed code, language is looked at as a resource to conduct action with, an idea that echoes the notions put forth by [[Speech act theory|speech act]] theorists such as [[J.L. Austin|Austin]] and [[John Searle|Searle]], [[Interactional sociolinguistics|interactional sociolinguists]] such as [[John J. Gumperz|Gumperz]], [[Conversation Analysis|conversation analysts]] such as [[Harvey Sacks|Sacks]], [[Schegloff]], and Goodwin, as well as others such as [[Goffman]], all of whom were or are active in fields outside of linguistics, including language philosophy, sociology, and anthropology. Harris claims that to not know what a word means is to not know what to do with the words, to not know “how to integrate the occurrence of the word into enough of our linguistic experience to satisfy the requirement of the [present] case”.<ref>Harris, 1998 (cited by Pablé, 2009).</ref> Pablé explores the integrationist views of language in terms of the naming practices related to castles in [[Bellinzona, Switzerland]].<ref name=pable2010/><ref name=pable2009>Pablé, 2009.{{clarify|date=April 2015}}</ref> By asking locals the directions to castles using non-standard names for the castles, Pablé elicited various forms by which the locals referred to them, highlighting the idea that references to the places were “highly context sensitive” and that the “meaning” is created on the spot,<ref name=pable2009/> and that “speakers always make sense of language in light of their own experience”.<ref name=pable2010/>
According to integrationist principles, the separation of linguistic phenomena into distinct parts of study is a fundamental error in the conceptualization of language. In 'The Language Myth', Harris postulates that the isolation and subsequent segregational approach of orthodox linguistics is a result of the fact of language itself being the descriptive medium for its own study. A problem arises when we consider words as stand-ins for things. When we then have a word for a language, the word misleads us to consider languages to be things out there in the world rather than real time, second order processes undergoing constant adjustment.<ref name=":0" />
==Epistemological overlaps== Integrationism overlaps with recent and not so recent epistemologies concerning communication and interaction. It retains an interest in understanding the system of language-making as an emergent, context-bound, and fundamentally human activity. This view is philosophically consistent with sociocultural theories such as activity theory where the historicity of human experience is recognized to have implications on our activities in ways that shape how they unfold.<ref>Cole & Hatano, 2007.</ref>
Integrationist linguistics overlaps with pragmatic and phenomenological approaches such as ethnomethodology and conversation analysis. The latter being rightly susceptible to a written and spoken word bias yet this is not without current attempts to broaden and include a wider range of semiotic contingencies into analyses. The more fundamental overlap is epistemological. Harold Garfinkel's (1994) ethnomethodological policies prioritize the context of interaction with strict objection to analytic presupposed systems of any kind other than that which is made so by the sequentially ordered interactions of participants. Conversation analysts have developed an empirical approach stemming from those policies where spoken and written words are centralized. A recent decentralizing move to the analysis and theorization of multimodal sequential analysis is very much consistent with an integrationist point of view.<ref>Goodwin, 2000.</ref><ref>Streeck, 1996.</ref>
==Integrationism and identity== While integrationism has been in existence for over three decades, advocating against the “language myth”<ref name=":0">Harris, 1981.</ref> and indicating that linguistic sign alone cannot function as the basis of an independent, self-sufficient form of communication, but depends for effectiveness on its integration with non-verbal activities of many different kinds, some integrationists have recently directed this perspective to revisit another important concept in sociolinguistics – “social identity”.
This integrational view of identity concurs with the sociocultural perspective that identity is not a rigid and static system predetermined on the basis of either social class, gender, ethnicity, age or education, but rather a discursive and constantly emerging experience that is locally shared and situationally evoked. On the other hand, however, stressing that identity cannot be examined exclusively from an individual’s integrational practice (including both linguistic and non-linguistic practice), integrationists cast doubt on the way sociocultural approach analyzes identity by specifically questioning three of the latter’s tenets: (i) data, (ii) phenomenological inductivism,<ref>Allan, 2003.</ref> and (iii) indirect indexicality.<ref name=phc2010/> They point out an intrinsic controversy that while identity, as the speaker’s first-order experience, is highly context-dependent, the attempt to detect identity merely through inspecting the linguistic components in the tape-recorded data and interpret the data through postulating the existence of linguistically pre-labeled “concrete universals” (e.g. ‘varieties of language’, ‘style’) is actually de-contextualizing the speakers’ identity. Also, they identified another conflict in the sociocultural approach of interpreting a speaker’s identity between the claim of a socially indexical value of linguistic features (“social marker”) that is beyond a single occurrence and the one of locally indexical value of linguistic features that is analyzable only in term of one specific local context.
Compared with sociolinguistic perspective on social identity, integrationists emphasize the integrational phenomenon that occurs when we converse with each other. Sociolinguists concentrate on how people utilize linguistic structures and items, cultural norms, and macro identities that they are normatively assigned in conversation. Based on utterances, sociolinguists attempt to capture speakers’ positionality and relationality in terms of identity, emergence of identity, and indexicality of the language that speakers used.<ref>Bucholtz & Hall, 2005.</ref> It is problematic to integrationists that sociolinguists only focus upon what is said. In other words, sociolinguists take language as an independent structure that can be isolated from the ongoing conversation. Integrationists argue that utterances cannot be dissociated from the context where he utters statements. Utterances have to be integrated with the activities, linguistic and non-linguistic, at that moment.
In conclusion, from an integrational view, “social identity” is rather a “meta-discursive label used by lay speakers to cope with their everyday first-order experience”<ref name=phc2010/> than a term or object of scientific study that is static and communicationally predetermined. In other words, along with their refusal of language as a static code system to be decoded for meaning transmission, they specifically emphasize that identity is not amenable to scientific description, as “sign-making and sign-interpreting are ‘private’ and cannot be detached from an individual’s integrational activities in the here-and-now”.<ref name=phc2010/> The remaining question for integrationists is how to study ‘identity’ then. One suggestion integrationalists may be more up to is to treat what is displayed in the temporal situations as “beings” and “becomings” rather than fixed identities, and study it multimodally, which is to take different modalities and time scales into consideration, instead of merely relying on the pre-labelled linguistic features.
==The implications of first-order and second-order language on reading comprehension== According to the [[United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO),<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110624104016/http://www.unescobkk.org/resources/online-materials/aims/uis-aims-activities/uis-aims-and-literacy-assessment/ What is Literacy?] (archive), UNESCO Office in Bangkok: UIS-AIMS and Literacy Assessment</ref> literacy is defined as the ability to identify, understand, interpret, create, communicate, compute and use printed and written materials associated with varying contexts. In other words, the ability to read and write does not only to fulfill one’s own need but also to communicate with the community and society where one stays. With regard to it, this section first focuses on the distinction between spoken language (first-order language) and written language (second-order language)<ref name=krav>Kravchenko, 2009.</ref> and how reading comprehension is achieved, and then aims at the impact of technology-enhanced interaction on reading comprehension.
Traditionally, spoken language and written language are regarded as the two sides of the same coin<ref name=krav/><ref>Linell, 2009.</ref> In other words, written language is believed to fully represent its corresponding spoken language. Therefore, educators believe by teaching words, or the symbolization of phonetic signs, students are equipped with the literacy to understand the written texts. However, it is often the case that students have a hard time understanding and interpreting a poem even though they know every single word. The glittering example reveals the problem of treating spoken language and written language as the same and implies the need to treat them differently.
According to Kravchenko, spoken language and written language are different in that spoken language is temporal and local, while written language is atemporal and non-local.<ref name=krav/> The understanding of spoken language relies on the common knowledge shared by the participants who are involved in the conversation, and the cognition required is situated and highly interactional. As for written language, the understanding takes place when the text is written (product) rather than is being written (process). Therefore, it is less interactional. Despite the difference, the understanding of both linguistic systems calls for the appropriate background knowledge. An example adapted from Kravchenko is that if a traveler wants to check in and the clerk tells him/her, “I’ll be back in 20 minutes”, the traveler may check the watch and calculate when to come back for the check-in, so he/she does not have to stand at the front desk for 20 minutes. However, if the traveler sees a note on the front desk saying, “I’ll be back in 20 minutes”, he/she may be baffled due to no point of reference, so he/she does not know how long is needed.<ref name=krav/> This example shows that it takes more efforts to establish background knowledge for the understanding of written language than spoken language. By extension, successful reading comprehension depends upon the establishment of shared knowledge between writers and readers.
With the development of technologies, written language includes not only printed work but also hypertexts. Because of the new genres of written language, new literacy is needed. Kravchenko maintained that literacy is the knowledge of using knowledge, so students have to develop the ability of reasoning and judgment based on the written texts.<ref name=krav/> Jenkins et al. go further by claiming that the form of reasoning plays a more important role than the content of learning in the era of technology-enhanced interaction.<ref>Jenkins et al., 2006.</ref> To put it another way, the content can be easily stored and retrieved by means of technologies, so the practice of reasoning centers on how to generate, evaluate, interpret, and deploy the electronic resources. Different electronic resources can provide different affordances, so one of the aims of teaching new literacy is to help students develop the ability of knowing what functions that the certain electronic resource is good at. For instance, the text mediation through computers can facilitate the thinking, reflecting, and revising of one’s own thought.<ref>Lotman, 1988.</ref><ref>Wertsh & Biven, 1992.</ref> Videos, with the visual and auditory modality, can better help knowledge acquisition than pictures, which have the visual modality alone.<ref>Mayer, 2001.</ref>
The hypertexts available online enable readers to create their own reading paths and recontextualize the resources of websites.<ref name=bt2010>Baldry and Thibault, 2010.</ref> Through the recontextualization, the thematic regions and semiotic formations are more idiosyncratic than fixed. The readers play a role in picking up the meaning through the created reading paths. According to Harris, linguistic signs should be understood with non-verbal activities.<ref>Harris, 2010.</ref> In addition to reading the hypertexts, the readers have access to other non-textual resources online, such as pictures, diagrams, videos, etc. The use of those non-verbal semiotic resources within the texts has its function and offers affordances to the readers to make meaning.<ref name=bt2010/>

'''Jaroslav Zvěřina''' {{Audio|Jaroslav zverina.ogg|Czech pronunciation}} (born on 18 December 1942 in [[Třebíč]]) is a [[Politics of the Czech Republic|Czech]] [[politician]] and former [[Member of the European Parliament]] with the [[Civic Democratic Party (Czech Republic)|Civic Democratic Party]], part of the [[European Democrats]] and sits on the [[European Parliament]]'s [[Committee on Legal Affairs]]. He was candidate also in European Parliament election in 2009, but he was not reelected.
He is a substitute for the [[Committee on Culture and Education]] and a vice-chair of the Delegation for relations with Japan.
==Education== * 1965: Doctor of Medicine (Faculty of Medicine, Charles University, Hradec Králové) * 1990: holder of the postgraduate qualification 'Candidate of Sciences' and senior lecturer (First Faculty of Medicine, Charles University, Prague)
==Career== * 1965-1969: Doctor * 1969-1977: Specialised doctor * 1977-1992: Research fellow * since 1989: Head of the Institute of Sexology of the First Faculty of Medicine, Charles University, Prague * since 1994: Chairman of the Tábor district association of ODS (Civic Democratic Party) * since 1994: Member of Tábor Town Council * 1998: Vice-Chairman of the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Parliament of the Czech Republic]][https://web.archive.org/web/20050426084643/http://www.psp.cz/cgi-bin/eng/] * 1998-2002: Chairman of the Committee for European Integration of the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Parliament of the Czech Republic]][https://web.archive.org/web/20050426084643/http://www.psp.cz/cgi-bin/eng/] * 2002-2004: Vice-Chairman of the Committee for European Affairs of the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Parliament of the Czech Republic]][https://web.archive.org/web/20050426084643/http://www.psp.cz/cgi-bin/eng/] * since 1990: Chairman of the Sexological Society of the Czech Medical Association * since 2001: Member of the supervisory board of the benevolent society 'Česká hlava'
==Cooperation== *[[Konrad Adenauer Foundation]]
==See also== * [[European Parliament election, 2004 (Czech Republic)]]
